
This is my first go at this challenge question, and I like the difficulty. It certainly isn't one that you complete in a day. My goal for this problem: 

-----Already Done -----
Read the quesetions in and store them
Assign them thier spots in Vector space

------- WOrking on ------ 
Tf-IDF weights 
Time Complexity 

------ TO DO ------ 
Set up the features I am going to use: 
    KNN 
    Vector Space - Euclidian Distane, Cos Similarity 
    * for the basics of this questions I was just going to use 3 features *
Build optimizing algorithm so that it can balance the weights of each feature, to match closest with the Evaluation Data
    


<span class="rendered_qtext">When a user adds a question to Quora, we automatically suggest topics which might be relevant to the question. For example, a question about Dijkstra&#039;s algorithm would probably fit well under the topics &quot;Algorithms&quot; and &quot;Graph Theory&quot;.<br /><br />We have a pretty good machine learning system in place for generating these topics, but it could always be better. Your goal in this task is to design a question topic labeler.<br /><br />The input data consists of a training dataset of <span class="render_latex">[math]T[/math]</span> questions and an evaluation dataset of <span class="render_latex">[math]E[/math]</span>&nbsp; questions. Your labeler should suggest 10 topics for each question in the evaluation set, ordered by relevance.<br /><br /><b>Input Format</b><br />The first line consists of two space-separated integers <span class="render_latex">[math]T[/math]</span> and <span class="render_latex">[math]E\, (1 \leq T \leq 20000, 1 \leq E \leq 1000)[/math]</span> .<br /><br />The next <span class="render_latex">[math]2T[/math]</span>&nbsp; lines provide the training dataset. Each question in the training dataset is described by two lines:<br /><br /><ul><li>One integer <span class="render_latex">[math]N\, (1 \leq N \leq 25)[/math]</span> , followed by <span class="render_latex">[math]N[/math]</span> positive integers (below 250) representing the topic IDs of the question in no particular order. On average, there are approximately 3 topics per question in the dataset.</li><li>One string (between 1 and 500 printable ASCII characters), the question text. The average question text length is 70 characters.</li></ul><br />The next <span class="render_latex">[math]E[/math]</span> lines provide the evaluation dataset. Each question in the evaluation dataset is described by one line (between 1 and 500 ASCII characters), the question text.<br /><br /><b>Output Format</b><br />There are <span class="render_latex">[math]T[/math]</span> lines in total. The <span class="render_latex">[math]i[/math]</span>-th line contains 10 space-separated integers, each representing the topic id of a suggestion for the <span class="render_latex">[math]i[/math]</span>-th question in the evaluation dataset. To maximize your score, topic suggestions for a question should be ordered in descending order of relevance.<br /><br /><b>Sample Input</b><br /><pre class="prettyprint linenums">6 4
3 1 2 4
What is the meaning of life?
7 1 2 5 8 9 11 15
What is Quora?
2 14 178
What are the best Google calendar hacks?
3 117 93 125
Why does government of China not value the freedom of speech?
2 65 164
What is the best piece of design ever?
5 197 183 29 170 143
What was the last conversation you had with your father?
Are programming contests fun?
What is machine learning?
How do you code in C++?
Is it possible to sort in linear time?</pre><br /><br />Note: a more comprehensive sample input (with the same training data made available during evaluation) is available here (<span class="qlink_container"><a href="http://qim.s3.amazonaws.com/labeler_sample.in" rel="noopener nofollow" target="_blank" onclick="return Q.openUrl(this);" class="external_link" onmouseover="return require(&quot;qtext&quot;).tooltip(this, &quot;amazonaws.com&quot;)">input</a></span>, <span class="qlink_container"><a href="http://qim.s3.amazonaws.com/labeler_sample.ans" rel="noopener nofollow" target="_blank" onclick="return Q.openUrl(this);" class="external_link" onmouseover="return require(&quot;qtext&quot;).tooltip(this, &quot;amazonaws.com&quot;)">correct topics</a></span>). You can use <span class="qlink_container"><a href="http://qim.s3.amazonaws.com/labeler_checker.py" rel="noopener nofollow" target="_blank" onclick="return Q.openUrl(this);" class="external_link" onmouseover="return require(&quot;qtext&quot;).tooltip(this, &quot;amazonaws.com&quot;)">this script</a></span> to score your output for the sample dataset.<br /><br /><b>Sample Output</b><br /><pre class="prettyprint linenums">1 2 5 3 7 9 11 10 14 15
2 9 29 3 117 197 1 183 178 15
15 197 170 143 8 5 1 7 2 14
1 8 14 164 125 15 2 65 164 3</pre><br /><br /><b>Scoring</b><br />Your score for each question is determined as follows:<br /><br /><span class="render_latex">[math]\frac{{}\sum\limits_{i=0}^9{\sqrt{10 - i} \cdot (guess_i \in questionTopics)}}{\sum\limits_{i=0}^{min(|questionTopics|, 10) - 1}{\sqrt{10 - i}}}[/math]</span><br /><br />Your raw score is the sum of each question score.<br /><br /><span class="render_latex">[math]minScore[/math]</span> = raw score for classifier that guesses 10 most frequent topics.<br /><br />Your final score is <span class="render_latex">[math]200 \cdot \frac{yourRawScore - minScore}{E - minScore}[/math]</span>.<br /><br /><b>Resource Limits</b><br />Your program is limited to 512 MB of memory and must run in 60 seconds or less.</span><iframe src="https://www.hackerrank.com/work/embedview/16jafncqb/173214t2h" width="100%" frameborder="0" height="230px"></iframe></div><div class="Challenge" id="duplicate"><h2>Duplicate</h2><span class="rendered_qtext">Quora uses a combination of machine learning algorithms and moderation to ensure high-quality content on the site. High question and answer quality has helped Quora distinguish itself from other Q&amp;A sites on the web.<br /><br />As the number of questions on Quora grows, there is an increasing likelihood that a new question may be a duplicate of an existing question. The text of the questions can vary significantly, but semantically might mean the same thing. We rely on human judgment to determine if 2 questions are considered to be duplicates and merge these questions together on Quora.<br /><br />For this task, given Quora question text and topic data, determine if any 2 given pairs of questions are considered duplicates or not.<br /><br />The following fields of raw data are given in JSON representing each question:<br /><br /><ul><li>question_key (string): Unique identifier for the question.</li><li>question_text (string): Text of the question.</li><li>context_topic (object): The primary topic of a question, if present. Null otherwise. The topic object will contain a name (string) and followers (integer) count.</li><li>topics (array of objects): All topics on a question, including the primary topic. Each topic object will contain a name (string) and followers (integer) count.</li><li>view_count (int): Number of views on the question.</li></ul><br />After the raw data for each question, the list of known duplicate questions and non-duplicate questions among all the given questions are shared as pairs of questions with an integer representing whether that pair is a duplicate or not (1 for duplicate and 0 for non-duplicate). All other pairings of any 2 questions that are not in this list are unknown to be duplicates or not and the test set will come from this. Note that all questions referenced by the training and test sets will be present in the list of raw question data.<br /><br /><b>Input Format</b><br /><ul><li>The first line will contain an integer <span class="render_latex">[math]1 \leq Q \leq 60,000[/math]</span>, which represents the number of lines of questions in the training data to follow.</li><li>The next Q lines will contain JSON encoded fields of raw question data.</li><li>The next line will contain an integer <span class="render_latex">[math]1 \leq D \leq 25,000[/math]</span>, which represent the number of lines of duplicate question pairs in the training data to follow.</li><li>The next D lines will each contain 2 known duplicate questions identified by their unique question_key and an integer representing whether the pair are duplicates (1 for duplicate, 0 for non-duplicate) separated by spaces. (e.g. “abc def 1”)</li><li>The next line will contain an integer <span class="render_latex">[math]1 \leq N \leq 3,000[/math]</span> for the number of lines of test question pair data to follow.</li><li>The next N lines will each contain 2 test questions identified by their unique question_key separated by a space.</li></ul><br /><b>Output Format</b><br /><ul><li>N lines of 2 question keys and an integer representing whether the 2 test questions are duplicates (1 for duplicate and 0 for non-duplicate). (e.g. “ghi jkl 0”)</li></ul><br /><b>Sample Input</b><br /><pre class="prettyprint linenums">3

{&quot;view_count&quot;: 773, &quot;question_text&quot;: &quot;Which is the most intelligent alien or alien species in fiction?&quot;, &quot;context_topic&quot;: {&quot;followers&quot;: 130960, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Science Fiction (genre)&quot;}, &quot;topics&quot;: [{&quot;followers&quot;: 48, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Science Fiction Books&quot;}, {&quot;followers&quot;: 130960, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Science Fiction (genre)&quot;}, {&quot;followers&quot;: 1182, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Extraterrestrial Intelligence&quot;}, {&quot;followers&quot;: 50056, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Extraterrestrial Life&quot;}, {&quot;followers&quot;: 3883, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Science Fiction Movies&quot;}], &quot;follow_count&quot;: 9, &quot;question_key&quot;: &quot;AAEAAJ/qtRMKkzXyA0tvjyz5tPRWgYizvOkCr9Z9CdJ4cood&quot;, &quot;age&quot;: 413}
{&quot;view_count&quot;: 3522, &quot;question_text&quot;: &quot;What is the best way to keep bookmarks?&quot;, &quot;context_topic&quot;: {&quot;followers&quot;: 513, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Bookmarking&quot;}, &quot;topics&quot;: [{&quot;followers&quot;: 1136, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Pocket (app)&quot;}, {&quot;followers&quot;: 9, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;ReadItLater&quot;}, {&quot;followers&quot;: 1625, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Pinboard&quot;}, {&quot;followers&quot;: 1275, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Social Bookmarking&quot;}, {&quot;followers&quot;: 513, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Bookmarking&quot;}, {&quot;followers&quot;: 5604, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Delicious (web application)&quot;}, {&quot;followers&quot;: 4359, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Instapaper&quot;}, {&quot;followers&quot;: 85, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Web Bookmarks&quot;}], &quot;follow_count&quot;: 62, &quot;question_key&quot;: &quot;AAEAADJKxcVF6l23JZvf1Fz+QrKr35CTlMKayNnZebc8dQAY&quot;, &quot;age&quot;: 1193}
{&quot;view_count&quot;: 390, &quot;question_text&quot;: &quot;What is best for online bookmarks?&quot;, &quot;context_topic&quot;: null, &quot;topics&quot;: [{&quot;followers&quot;: 1275, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Social Bookmarking&quot;}, {&quot;followers&quot;: 285, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Social Bookmarking Websites&quot;}, {&quot;followers&quot;: 513, &quot;name&quot;: &quot;Bookmarking&quot;}], &quot;follow_count&quot;: 4, &quot;question_key&quot;: &quot;AAEAAO3FKYrsnYH9uKAOnnXfYrGGTVFA3uzHz+Vltm5Ssii3&quot;, &quot;age&quot;: 1211}
2

You can use <span class="qlink_container"><a href="http://qim.s3.amazonaws.com/duplicate_checker.py" rel="noopener nofollow" target="_blank" onclick="return Q.openUrl(this);" class="external_link" onmouseover="return require(&quot;qtext&quot;).tooltip(this, &quot;amazonaws.com&quot;)">this script</a></span> to score your output for the sample dataset.<br /><br /><b>Sample Output</b><br /><code class="prettyprint inline">AAEAAJ/qtRMKkzXyA0tvjyz5tPRWgYizvOkCr9Z9CdJ4cood AAEAAO3FKYrsnYH9uKAOnnXfYrGGTVFA3uzHz+Vltm5Ssii3 0</code><br /><br /><b>Scoring</b><br /><h2></h2>You will get 1 point for each pair of questions that you predicted correctly.<br /><br />Your raw score is the sum of all points for all pairs of questions in the test case (<span class="render_latex">[math]N[/math]</span>).<br /><br />Your final score is <span class="render_latex">[math]200 \cdot \frac{yourRawScore}{N}[/math]</span>.<br /><br /><b>Resource Limits</b><br /><h2></h2>Your program is limited to 1024 MB of memory and must run in 60 seconds or less.<br /><br /><b>Notes</b><br /><ul><li>This data set is not representative of all the data in Quora but intentionally sampled to make a good challenge to solve.</li></ul></span><iframe src="https://www.hackerrank.com/work/embedview/16jafncqb/14amr2mdi" width="100%" frameborder="0" height="230px"></iframe></div><div class="Challenge" id="answered"><h2>Answered</h2><span class="rendered_qtext"><div class="qtext_image_wrapper"><canvas class="qtext_image_placeholder landscape qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" width="572.0" height="455.161634103" data-src="data:image/PNG;base64,"></canvas><img class="landscape qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed lazy_loaded lazy_loading" src="" data-src="https://qph.ec.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-061af92d06f98bac9353ace89d9d2cec?convert_to_webp=true" master_src="https://qph.ec.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-cf07e6d9d2cdc53dca5aba3ef2a17694?convert_to_webp=true" master_w="1126" master_h="896"/></div><br />Quora uses a combination of machine learning algorithms and moderation to ensure high-quality content on the site. High question and answer quality has helped Quora distinguish itself from other Q&amp;A sites on the web.<br /><br />As we get many questions every day, a challenge we have is to figure out good, interesting and meaningful questions from the bad. What questions are valid ones that can be answered? What questions attract reputable answers that then get upvoted? Can you tell which questions will likely get answers quickly, so that we can surface them in real-time to our users?<br /><br /><i>For this task, given Quora question text and topic data, predict whether a question gets an upvoted answer within 1 day.</i><br /><br /><b>Input Format</b><br />The first line contains N. N questions follow, each being a valid json object. The following fields of raw data are given in json.<br /><ul><li>question_key (string): Unique identifier for the question.</li><li>question_text (string): Text of the question.</li><li>context_topic (object): The primary topic of a question, if present. Null otherwise. The topic object will contain a name (string) and followers (integer) count.</li><li>topics (array of objects): All topics on a question, including the primary topic. Each topic object will contain a name (string) and followers (integer) count.</li><li>anonymous (boolean): Whether the question was anonymous.</li><li>__ans__ (boolean): Whether the question got an up-voted answer within 1 day.</li></ul>This is immediately followed by an integer T.<br /><br />T questions follow, each being a valid json object.<br />The json contains all but one field <i>__ans__</i>.<br /><br /><b>Output Format</b><h2></h2>T rows of JSON encoded fields, with the <i>question_key</i> key containing the unique identifier given in the test data, and the predicted value keyed by <i>__ans__</i>.<br /><br /><b>Constraints</b><br />question_key is of ascii format.<br />question_text, name in topics and context_topic is of UTF-8 format.<br />0 &lt;= followers &lt;= 106<br />9000 &lt;= N &lt;= 45000<br />1000 &lt;= T &lt;= 5000<br /><br /><b>Training Data</b><h2></h2>Sample testcases can be downloaded <span class="qlink_container"><a href="http://hr-testcases.s3.amazonaws.com/688/sample.zip" rel="noopener nofollow" target="_blank" onclick="return Q.openUrl(this);" class="external_link" onmouseover="return require(&quot;qtext&quot;).tooltip(this, &quot;amazonaws.com&quot;)">here</a></span> and used for offline training if desired.<br /><br /><b>Scoring</b><h2></h2>The answers are evaluated by accuracy.<br /><br /><pre class="prettyprint linenums">Number correct classified / Total input size * 100%
</pre><br /><br />The training and test set each will have approximately an equal number of each boolean type.<br /><br />Your score will be based only on the hidden input. The sample input is only for your convenience.</span><iframe src="https://www.hackerrank.com/work/embedview/r18igr3i/17323f1ep" width="100%" frameborder="0" height="230px"></iframe></div><div class="Challenge" id="interest"><h2>Interest</h2><span class="rendered_qtext"><div class="qtext_image_wrapper"><canvas class="qtext_image_placeholder portrait qtext_image zoomable_in_feed" width="538" height="616" data-src="data:image/PNG;base64,"></canvas><img class="portrait qtext_image zoomable_in_feed lazy_loaded lazy_loading" src="" data-src="https://qph.ec.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-ef45a036b277fe21c4a0696e8b2f88d4?convert_to_webp=true" master_src="https://qph.ec.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-ef45a036b277fe21c4a0696e8b2f88d4?convert_to_webp=true" master_w="538" master_h="616"/></div><br />Quora uses machine learning algorithms to try to generate interesting news feeds and digest emails for people.<br /><br />Before a question gets an answer, we’d like to be able to make use of all the available information we have to be able to predict how interesting or relevant the question is to people. Ideally, we’d like to be able to tell this in real-time as soon as a few people have viewed it, by measuring the people following the question as a proxy of interest. Can you tell what questions will get the most followers?<br /><br /><i>For this task, given Quora question text and topic data for questions with 0 visible answers, predict the ratio of viewers to followers.</i><br /><br /><b>Input Format</b><br />The first line contains N. N questions follow, each being a valid json object. The following fields of raw data are given in json.<br /><ul><li>question_key (string): Unique identifier for the question.</li><li>question_text (string): Text of the question.</li><li>context_topic (object): The primary topic of a question, if present. Null otherwise. The topic object will contain a name (string) and followers (integer) count.</li><li>topics (array of objects): All topics on a question, including the primary topic. Each topic object will contain a name (string) and followers (integer) count.</li><li>anonymous (boolean): Whether the question was anonymous.</li><li>__ans__ (float): The ratio of viewers to followers of the question.</li></ul><br />This is immediately followed by an integer T.<br />T questions follow, each being a valid json object.<br />The json contains all but one field <i>__ans__</i>.<br /><br /><b>Output Format</b><h2></h2>T rows of JSON encoded fields, with the <i>question_key</i> key containing the unique identifier given in the test data, and the predicted value keyed by <i>__ans__</i>.<br /><br /><b>Constraints</b><h2></h2>question_key is of ascii format.<br />question_text, name in topics and context_topic is of UTF-8 format.<br />0 &lt;= followers &lt;= 106<br />9000 &lt;= N &lt;= 45000<br />1000 &lt;= T &lt;= 5000<br /><br /><b>Training Data</b><h2></h2>Sample testcases can be downloaded <span class="qlink_container"><a href="http://hr-testcases.s3.amazonaws.com/689/sample.zip" rel="noopener nofollow" target="_blank" onclick="return Q.openUrl(this);" class="external_link" onmouseover="return require(&quot;qtext&quot;).tooltip(this, &quot;amazonaws.com&quot;)">here</a></span> and used for offline training if desired.<br /><br /><b>Scoring</b><h2></h2><h2></h2>Your solution is evaluated by a Root Mean Squared Logarithmic Error (RMSLE) metric. We then calculate a final score by how close it reaches a target score of 0.5, and scale that by 100%.<br /><br /><div class="qtext_image_wrapper"><canvas class="qtext_image_placeholder landscape qtext_image zoomable_in_feed" width="310" height="56" data-src="data:image/PNG;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAoAAAACCAIAAADuA9qHAAAAN0lEQVR4nAXBsQkAQAgDwAhWivsP+hgbI39n3S1J0u5mJgCSVfXeA+Ak7253JZkZgJlx94gA8AG6HCCj86jYFQAAAABJRU5ErkJggg=="></canvas><img class="landscape qtext_image zoomable_in_feed lazy_loaded lazy_loading" src="" data-src="https://qph.ec.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-3930fcc7bfc2e69a44e40891a29f03d6?convert_to_webp=true" master_src="https://qph.ec.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-3930fcc7bfc2e69a44e40891a29f03d6?convert_to_webp=true" master_w="310" master_h="56"/></div><br />Your score will be based only on the hidden input. The sample input is only for your convenience.</span><iframe src="https://www.hackerrank.com/work/embedview/r18igr3i/sq4l8bf5" width="100%" frameborder="0" height="230px"></iframe></div><div class="Challenge" id="views"><h2>Views</h2><span class="rendered_qtext"><div class="qtext_image_wrapper"><canvas class="qtext_image_placeholder portrait qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" width="572.0" height="654.196850394" data-src="data:image/PNG;base64,"></canvas><img class="portrait qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed lazy_loaded lazy_loading" src="" data-src="https://qph.ec.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-9c9babc857108f935af8104e96a5f75c?convert_to_webp=true" master_src="https://qph.ec.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-22a0f1085131e8adfe892197f906c1b6?convert_to_webp=true" master_w="1016" master_h="1162"/></div><br />Quora uses a combination of machine learning algorithms and moderation to ensure high-quality content on the site. High question and answer quality has helped Quora distinguish itself from other Q&amp;A sites on the web.<br /><br />Not all of these questions are as interesting or appealing to people on the web. Can you tell what questions can organically attract the most viewers? What about questions that eventually become viral? Which questions are timeless and can sustain traffic?<br /><br /><i>For this task, given Quora question text, topic data, number of answers and number of people promoted to, predict the number of views per day in age of the question.</i><br /><br /><b>Input Format</b><h2></h2>The first line contains N. N questions follow, each being a valid json object. The following fields of raw data are given in json.<br /><ul><li>question_key (string): Unique identifier for the question.</li><li>question_text (string): Text of the question.</li><li>context_topic (object): The primary topic of a question, if present. Null otherwise. The topic object will contain a name (string) and followers (integer) count.</li><li>topics (array of objects): All topics on a question, including the primary topic. Each topic object will contain a name (string) and followers (integer) count.</li><li>anonymous (boolean): Whether the question was anonymous.</li><li>num_answers (integer): The number of visible non-collapsed answers the question has.</li><li>promoted_to (integer): The number of people the question was promoted to.</li><li>__ans__ (float): The ratio of viewers to age of the question in days.</li></ul><br />This is immediately followed by an integer T.<br />T questions follow, each being a valid json object.<br />The json contains all but one field <i>__ans__</i>.<br /><br /><b>Output Format</b><h2></h2><h2></h2>T rows of JSON encoded fields, with the <i>question_key</i> key containing the unique identifier given in the test data, and the predicted value keyed by <i>__ans__</i>.<br /><br /><b>Constraints</b><h2></h2>question_key is of ascii format.<br />question_text, name in topics and context_topic is of UTF-8 format.<br />0 &lt;= followers &lt;= 106<br />9000 &lt;= N &lt;= 45000<br />1000 &lt;= T &lt;= 5000<br /><br /><b>Training Data</b><br />Sample testcases can be downloaded <span class="qlink_container"><a href="http://hr-testcases.s3.amazonaws.com/691/sample.zip" rel="noopener nofollow" target="_blank" onclick="return Q.openUrl(this);" class="external_link" onmouseover="return require(&quot;qtext&quot;).tooltip(this, &quot;amazonaws.com&quot;)">here</a></span> and used for offline training if desired.<br /><br /><b>Scoring</b><h2></h2>Your solution is evaluated by a Root Mean Squared Logarithmic Error (RMSLE) metric. We then calculate a final score by how close it reaches a target score of 0.5, and scale that by 100%.<br /><br /><div class="qtext_image_wrapper"><canvas class="qtext_image_placeholder landscape qtext_image zoomable_in_feed" width="310" height="56" data-src="data:image/PNG;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAoAAAACCAIAAADuA9qHAAAAN0lEQVR4nAXBsQkAQAgDwAhWivsP+hgbI39n3S1J0u5mJgCSVfXeA+Ak7253JZkZgJlx94gA8AG6HCCj86jYFQAAAABJRU5ErkJggg=="></canvas><img class="landscape qtext_image zoomable_in_feed lazy_loaded lazy_loading" src="" data-src="https://qph.ec.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-3930fcc7bfc2e69a44e40891a29f03d6?convert_to_webp=true" master_src="https://qph.ec.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-3930fcc7bfc2e69a44e40891a29f03d6?convert_to_webp=true" master_w="310" master_h="56"/></div><br />Your score will be based only on the hidden input. The sample input is only for your convenience.</span><iframe src="https://www.hackerrank.com/work/embedview/r18igr3i/np7so98q" width="100%" frameborder="0" height="230px"></iframe></div><div class="Challenge" id="typeahead_search"><h2>Typeahead Search</h2><span class="rendered_qtext"><div class="qtext_image_wrapper"><canvas class="qtext_image_placeholder landscape qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" width="572.0" height="254.314868805" data-src="data:image/PNG;base64,"></canvas>
